We are hiring!!!!Title: Project Management Specialist ILocation: San Diego, CA 92121Job Duration: 12 Months + (Possibilities chance of extension) DescriptionShift timing: 8am – 5pmInterview Process: initial phone screen, then onsite panel interviewIs There a Likelihood Of An Extension Past The Initial Duration: yes Essential Duties and Responsibilities:Requirements:Must have medical device experience.Previous project analyst or project coord experience supporting program managers in the pastStrong communication, must be able to communicate with upper leadershipAble to work independentlyBackground ExperienceScientific or engineering experience would be preferredEssential Duties and ResponsibilitiesThe incumbent may be asked to perform other function-related activities and the below-mentioned responsibilities as reasonably required by business needs. Supports a more senior project manager on programs with a broad multidisciplinary and or technical scope.Assists in maintaining master schedules, resources, and project budget.Assists in tracking, managing, and facilitating the resolution of project risks and issues.Processes and maintains design control documentation and Design History Files, per procedures.Maintains design control documentation supporting design inputs, risk, and other trace matrix data.Drafts core team-specific design control documents (e.g., project plans, traces) for team review.Coordinates design reviews, deliverables, and reviews information. Ensures action items are resolved and documented.Interacts with team members, including senior-level staff, in driving the completion of deliverables.Communicates status of project deliverables to core team leader, team members, and stakeholders.Other duties as assigned.Liaison with QA Auditors for audit of DHF, as needed.QualificationsEducation:BS Degree in Science or EngineeringProject Management coursework or certification desirable (e.g., CAPM, PMP)Experience:2 - 5 years of experience in a regulated industry, ideally supporting project teamsFamiliarity with Design Controls and Regulatory Requirements.SkillsTo perform this job successfully, an individual must be able to perform each essential duty satisfactorily. The requirements listed below are representative of the basic knowledge, skills, and/or abilities required:Knowledge of some aspects of project management (timelines, budget, financials)Proficient with the use of project management tools (e.g., MS Project, Smartsheet, JIRA, Asana, Planview) to manage projectsExcellent organization skills, and attention to detailAbility to interact effectively with personnel from top to bottom of the organization with diverse cultural and educational backgrounds.Good communication and problem-solving ability.

We are hiring!!!!Title: Project Management Specialist ILocation: San Diego, CA 92121Job Duration: 12 Months + (Possibilities chance of extension) DescriptionShift timing: 8am – 5pmInterview Process: initial phone screen, then onsite panel interviewIs There a Likelihood Of An Extension Past The Initial Duration: yes Essential Duties and Responsibilities:Requirements:Must have medical device experience.Previous project analyst or project coord experience supporting program managers in the pastStrong communication, must be able to communicate with upper leadershipAble to work independentlyBackground ExperienceScientific or engineering experience would be preferredEssential Duties and ResponsibilitiesThe incumbent may be asked to perform other function-related activities and the below-mentioned responsibilities as reasonably required by business needs. Supports a more senior project manager on programs with a broad multidisciplinary and or technical scope.Assists in maintaining master schedules, resources, and project budget.Assists in tracking, managing, and facilitating the resolution of project risks and issues.Processes and maintains design control documentation and Design History Files, per procedures.Maintains design control documentation supporting design inputs, risk, and other trace matrix data.Drafts core team-specific design control documents (e.g., project plans, traces) for team review.Coordinates design reviews, deliverables, and reviews information. Ensures action items are resolved and documented.Interacts with team members, including senior-level staff, in driving the completion of deliverables.Communicates status of project deliverables to core team leader, team members, and stakeholders.Other duties as assigned.Liaison with QA Auditors for audit of DHF, as needed.QualificationsEducation:BS Degree in Science or EngineeringProject Management coursework or certification desirable (e.g., CAPM, PMP)Experience:2 - 5 years of experience in a regulated industry, ideally supporting project teamsFamiliarity with Design Controls and Regulatory Requirements.SkillsTo perform this job successfully, an individual must be able to perform each essential duty satisfactorily. The requirements listed below are representative of the basic knowledge, skills, and/or abilities required:Knowledge of some aspects of project management (timelines, budget, financials)Proficient with the use of project management tools (e.g., MS Project, Smartsheet, JIRA, Asana, Planview) to manage projectsExcellent organization skills, and attention to detailAbility to interact effectively with personnel from top to bottom of the organization with diverse cultural and educational backgrounds.Good communication and problem-solving ability.

Təsəvvür et:– Oracle SQL bilirsən,– PL/SQL ilə sistem qurursan,– APEX ilə interfeysləri düzəldirsən,– Sistemi sazlayırsan,– Support verirsən,– Test edirsən,– Kredit məhsullarını da bilirsən…və bütün bunlar 2 il təcrübə ilə!Qardaş, bu 2 il NASA-da keçibsə, bəlkə mümkündür.Üstəlik "stressə davamlılıq" da vacibdir – çünki bu qədər işi bir adama verəndə davam gətirməsən, tətbiqi sistemlər deyil, namizəd çökür.Bəzən elə gəlir ki, vakansiya yox, Marvel üçün superqəhrəman kastinqidir.Əziz HR dostlar, biz developerik, transformer yox. We are hiring!!!!Title: Project Management Specialist ILocation: San Diego, CA 92121Job Duration: 12 Months + (Possibilities chance of extension) DescriptionShift timing: 8am – 5pmInterview Process: initial phone screen, then onsite panel interviewIs There a Likelihood Of An Extension Past The Initial Duration: yes Essential Duties and Responsibilities:Requirements:Must have medical device experience.Previous project analyst or project coord experience supporting program managers in the pastStrong communication, must be able to communicate with upper leadershipAble to work independentlyBackground ExperienceScientific or engineering experience would be preferredEssential Duties and ResponsibilitiesThe incumbent may be asked to perform other function-related activities and the below-mentioned responsibilities as reasonably required by business needs. Supports a more senior project manager on programs with a broad multidisciplinary and or technical scope.Assists in maintaining master schedules, resources, and project budget.Assists in tracking, managing, and facilitating the resolution of project risks and issues.Processes and maintains design control documentation and Design History Files, per procedures.Maintains design control documentation supporting design inputs, risk, and other trace matrix data.Drafts core team-specific design control documents (e.g., project plans, traces) for team review.Coordinates design reviews, deliverables, and reviews information. Ensures action items are resolved and documented.Interacts with team members, including senior-level staff, in driving the completion of deliverables.Communicates status of project deliverables to core team leader, team members, and stakeholders.Other duties as assigned.Liaison with QA Auditors for audit of DHF, as needed.QualificationsEducation:BS Degree in Science or EngineeringProject Management coursework or certification desirable (e.g., CAPM, PMP)Experience:2 - 5 years of experience in a regulated industry, ideally supporting project teamsFamiliarity with Design Controls and Regulatory Requirements.SkillsTo perform this job successfully, an individual must be able to perform each essential duty satisfactorily. The requirements listed below are representative of the basic knowledge, skills, and/or abilities required:Knowledge of some aspects of project management (timelines, budget, financials)Proficient with the use of project management tools (e.g., MS Project, Smartsheet, JIRA, Asana, Planview) to manage projectsExcellent organization skills, and attention to detailAbility to interact effectively with personnel from top to bottom of the organization with diverse cultural and educational backgrounds.Good communication and problem-solving ability.

"Hörmətli" Unibank və Unibank Careers paylaşılan bir vakansiya hekayəsi "SQL Developer axtarılır" – oxuyursan, amma sonda elə bil Iron Man axtarırlar.Vakansiyada ən az 6 şəxsin işi birləşdirilib:- Tətbiqi sistemlərin quraşdırılması (DevOps işi)- Problemlərin izlənməsi və həlli (Support və ya QA işi)- Proyektlərin hazırlanması (Developer işi)- APEX tətbiqlərinin təkmilləşdirilməsi (Frontend işi)- Testləşdirmə (Tester işi)- Kredit məhsulları sahəsində bilik (Business Analyst işi?) Təsəvvür et:– Oracle SQL bilirsən,– PL/SQL ilə sistem qurursan,– APEX ilə interfeysləri düzəldirsən,– Sistemi sazlayırsan,– Support verirsən,– Test edirsən,– Kredit məhsullarını da bilirsən…və bütün bunlar 2 il təcrübə ilə!Qardaş, bu 2 il NASA-da keçibsə, bəlkə mümkündür.Üstəlik "stressə davamlılıq" da vacibdir – çünki bu qədər işi bir adama verəndə davam gətirməsən, tətbiqi sistemlər deyil, namizəd çökür.Bəzən elə gəlir ki, vakansiya yox, Marvel üçün superqəhrəman kastinqidir.Əziz HR dostlar, biz developerik, transformer yox. We are hiring!!!!Title: Project Management Specialist ILocation: San Diego, CA 92121Job Duration: 12 Months + (Possibilities chance of extension) DescriptionShift timing: 8am – 5pmInterview Process: initial phone screen, then onsite panel interviewIs There a Likelihood Of An Extension Past The Initial Duration: yes Essential Duties and Responsibilities:Requirements:Must have medical device experience.Previous project analyst or project coord experience supporting program managers in the pastStrong communication, must be able to communicate with upper leadershipAble to work independentlyBackground ExperienceScientific or engineering experience would be preferredEssential Duties and ResponsibilitiesThe incumbent may be asked to perform other function-related activities and the below-mentioned responsibilities as reasonably required by business needs. Supports a more senior project manager on programs with a broad multidisciplinary and or technical scope.Assists in maintaining master schedules, resources, and project budget.Assists in tracking, managing, and facilitating the resolution of project risks and issues.Processes and maintains design control documentation and Design History Files, per procedures.Maintains design control documentation supporting design inputs, risk, and other trace matrix data.Drafts core team-specific design control documents (e.g., project plans, traces) for team review.Coordinates design reviews, deliverables, and reviews information. Ensures action items are resolved and documented.Interacts with team members, including senior-level staff, in driving the completion of deliverables.Communicates status of project deliverables to core team leader, team members, and stakeholders.Other duties as assigned.Liaison with QA Auditors for audit of DHF, as needed.QualificationsEducation:BS Degree in Science or EngineeringProject Management coursework or certification desirable (e.g., CAPM, PMP)Experience:2 - 5 years of experience in a regulated industry, ideally supporting project teamsFamiliarity with Design Controls and Regulatory Requirements.SkillsTo perform this job successfully, an individual must be able to perform each essential duty satisfactorily. The requirements listed below are representative of the basic knowledge, skills, and/or abilities required:Knowledge of some aspects of project management (timelines, budget, financials)Proficient with the use of project management tools (e.g., MS Project, Smartsheet, JIRA, Asana, Planview) to manage projectsExcellent organization skills, and attention to detailAbility to interact effectively with personnel from top to bottom of the organization with diverse cultural and educational backgrounds.Good communication and problem-solving ability.

"Hörmətli" Unibank və Unibank Careers paylaşılan bir vakansiya hekayəsi "SQL Developer axtarılır" – oxuyursan, amma sonda elə bil Iron Man axtarırlar.Vakansiyada ən az 6 şəxsin işi birləşdirilib:- Tətbiqi sistemlərin quraşdırılması (DevOps işi)- Problemlərin izlənməsi və həlli (Support və ya QA işi)- Proyektlərin hazırlanması (Developer işi)- APEX tətbiqlərinin təkmilləşdirilməsi (Frontend işi)- Testləşdirmə (Tester işi)- Kredit məhsulları sahəsində bilik (Business Analyst işi?) Təsəvvür et:– Oracle SQL bilirsən,– PL/SQL ilə sistem qurursan,– APEX ilə interfeysləri düzəldirsən,– Sistemi sazlayırsan,– Support verirsən,– Test edirsən,– Kredit məhsullarını da bilirsən…və bütün bunlar 2 il təcrübə ilə!Qardaş, bu 2 il NASA-da keçibsə, bəlkə mümkündür.Üstəlik "stressə davamlılıq" da vacibdir – çünki bu qədər işi bir adama verəndə davam gətirməsən, tətbiqi sistemlər deyil, namizəd çökür.Bəzən elə gəlir ki, vakansiya yox, Marvel üçün superqəhrəman kastinqidir.Əziz HR dostlar, biz developerik, transformer yox. 🚀 Master Your Interviews: A 10-Post Journey Post 6: “Why Do You Want to Leave Your Current Job?” — Without Sounding Bitter or FakeThis one always hits a nerve.You’re asked why you want to leave…So most people go for the usual fluff:“I’m just looking for new challenges.” Too vague. Too rehearsed. Too forgettable.Here’s a better way to handle it — with honesty, maturity, and actual signal.🎯 The 3C Rule: Clarity, Constructiveness, Confidence🔹 Clarity — Be real, not ranty. Bad reasons (even if true): ❌ “My company is toxic.” ❌ “There’s too much politics.”Better: ✅ “I’ve realized I do my best work in more collaborative cultures.” ✅ “I’m looking for a place that invests in learning and development.”🔹 Constructiveness — Focus on what you’re moving toward, not just what you’re running from.Bad: ❌ “I don’t like my team structure.” Good: ✅ “I’m looking for a setup where cross-functional teams collaborate closely. That’s where I thrive.”🔹 Confidence — Frame it like a professional making a growth decision.“Over the past year, I’ve taken on more ownership — led releases, mentored juniors, and handled customer escalations. But I’ve hit a growth ceiling. I’m now looking for a role where I can build, influence strategy, and keep leveling up.”🧠 Generic but Relatable Examples Across Roles:A marketer:“I’ve grown a lot in my current role — but I’ve been doing mostly execution. I’m now ready for a position with more strategic involvement.”A backend dev:“I’ve mastered a lot in my stack — but our product is monolithic. I’d love to work on more modern systems and distributed architecture.”🔁 Bottom Line: Don’t badmouth. Don’t oversell. Just show that you’re someone who reflects, grows, and makes intentional choices. That’s what hiring managers respect.You’re not just leaving — you’re moving forward.hashtag#InterviewTips hashtag#MasterYourInterviews hashtag#CareerGrowth hashtag#RealTalk hashtag#LinkedInAdvice hashtag#QA hashtag#QualityEngineering hashtag#Testing

🚀 Master Your Interviews: A 10-Post Journey Post 6: “Why Do You Want to Leave Your Current Job?” — Without Sounding Bitter or FakeThis one always hits a nerve.You’re asked why you want to leave…So most people go for the usual fluff:“I’m just looking for new challenges.” Too vague. Too rehearsed. Too forgettable.Here’s a better way to handle it — with honesty, maturity, and actual signal.🎯 The 3C Rule: Clarity, Constructiveness, Confidence🔹 Clarity — Be real, not ranty. Bad reasons (even if true): ❌ “My company is toxic.” ❌ “There’s too much politics.”Better: ✅ “I’ve realized I do my best work in more collaborative cultures.” ✅ “I’m looking for a place that invests in learning and development.”🔹 Constructiveness — Focus on what you’re moving toward, not just what you’re running from.Bad: ❌ “I don’t like my team structure.” Good: ✅ “I’m looking for a setup where cross-functional teams collaborate closely. That’s where I thrive.”🔹 Confidence — Frame it like a professional making a growth decision.“Over the past year, I’ve taken on more ownership — led releases, mentored juniors, and handled customer escalations. But I’ve hit a growth ceiling. I’m now looking for a role where I can build, influence strategy, and keep leveling up.”🧠 Generic but Relatable Examples Across Roles:A marketer:“I’ve grown a lot in my current role — but I’ve been doing mostly execution. I’m now ready for a position with more strategic involvement.”A backend dev:“I’ve mastered a lot in my stack — but our product is monolithic. I’d love to work on more modern systems and distributed architecture.”🔁 Bottom Line: Don’t badmouth. Don’t oversell. Just show that you’re someone who reflects, grows, and makes intentional choices. That’s what hiring managers respect.You’re not just leaving — you’re moving forward.hashtag#InterviewTips hashtag#MasterYourInterviews hashtag#CareerGrowth hashtag#RealTalk hashtag#LinkedInAdvice hashtag#QA hashtag#QualityEngineering hashtag#Testing

🚀 Master Your Interviews: A 10-Post Journey Post 6: “Why Do You Want to Leave Your Current Job?” — Without Sounding Bitter or FakeThis one always hits a nerve.You’re asked why you want to leave…So most people go for the usual fluff:“I’m just looking for new challenges.” Too vague. Too rehearsed. Too forgettable.Here’s a better way to handle it — with honesty, maturity, and actual signal.🎯 The 3C Rule: Clarity, Constructiveness, Confidence🔹 Clarity — Be real, not ranty. Bad reasons (even if true): ❌ “My company is toxic.” ❌ “There’s too much politics.”Better: ✅ “I’ve realized I do my best work in more collaborative cultures.” ✅ “I’m looking for a place that invests in learning and development.”🔹 Constructiveness — Focus on what you’re moving toward, not just what you’re running from.Bad: ❌ “I don’t like my team structure.” Good: ✅ “I’m looking for a setup where cross-functional teams collaborate closely. That’s where I thrive.”🔹 Confidence — Frame it like a professional making a growth decision.“Over the past year, I’ve taken on more ownership — led releases, mentored juniors, and handled customer escalations. But I’ve hit a growth ceiling. I’m now looking for a role where I can build, influence strategy, and keep leveling up.”🧠 Generic but Relatable Examples Across Roles:A marketer:“I’ve grown a lot in my current role — but I’ve been doing mostly execution. I’m now ready for a position with more strategic involvement.”A backend dev:“I’ve mastered a lot in my stack — but our product is monolithic. I’d love to work on more modern systems and distributed architecture.”🔁 Bottom Line: Don’t badmouth. Don’t oversell. Just show that you’re someone who reflects, grows, and makes intentional choices. That’s what hiring managers respect.You’re not just leaving — you’re moving forward.hashtag#InterviewTips hashtag#MasterYourInterviews hashtag#CareerGrowth hashtag#RealTalk hashtag#LinkedInAdvice hashtag#QA hashtag#QualityEngineering hashtag#Testing

🚀 Master Your Interviews: A 10-Post Journey Post 6: “Why Do You Want to Leave Your Current Job?” — Without Sounding Bitter or FakeThis one always hits a nerve.You’re asked why you want to leave…So most people go for the usual fluff:“I’m just looking for new challenges.” Too vague. Too rehearsed. Too forgettable.Here’s a better way to handle it — with honesty, maturity, and actual signal.🎯 The 3C Rule: Clarity, Constructiveness, Confidence🔹 Clarity — Be real, not ranty. Bad reasons (even if true): ❌ “My company is toxic.” ❌ “There’s too much politics.”Better: ✅ “I’ve realized I do my best work in more collaborative cultures.” ✅ “I’m looking for a place that invests in learning and development.”🔹 Constructiveness — Focus on what you’re moving toward, not just what you’re running from.Bad: ❌ “I don’t like my team structure.” Good: ✅ “I’m looking for a setup where cross-functional teams collaborate closely. That’s where I thrive.”🔹 Confidence — Frame it like a professional making a growth decision.“Over the past year, I’ve taken on more ownership — led releases, mentored juniors, and handled customer escalations. But I’ve hit a growth ceiling. I’m now looking for a role where I can build, influence strategy, and keep leveling up.”🧠 Generic but Relatable Examples Across Roles:A marketer:“I’ve grown a lot in my current role — but I’ve been doing mostly execution. I’m now ready for a position with more strategic involvement.”A backend dev:“I’ve mastered a lot in my stack — but our product is monolithic. I’d love to work on more modern systems and distributed architecture.”🔁 Bottom Line: Don’t badmouth. Don’t oversell. Just show that you’re someone who reflects, grows, and makes intentional choices. That’s what hiring managers respect.You’re not just leaving — you’re moving forward.hashtag#InterviewTips hashtag#MasterYourInterviews hashtag#CareerGrowth hashtag#RealTalk hashtag#LinkedInAdvice hashtag#QA hashtag#QualityEngineering hashtag#Testing

We are hiring!!!!Title: Project Management Specialist ILocation: San Diego, CA 92121Job Duration: 12 Months + (Possibilities chance of extension) DescriptionShift timing: 8am – 5pmInterview Process: initial phone screen, then onsite panel interviewIs There a Likelihood Of An Extension Past The Initial Duration: yes Essential Duties and Responsibilities:Requirements:Must have medical device experience.Previous project analyst or project coord experience supporting program managers in the pastStrong communication, must be able to communicate with upper leadershipAble to work independentlyBackground ExperienceScientific or engineering experience would be preferredEssential Duties and ResponsibilitiesThe incumbent may be asked to perform other function-related activities and the below-mentioned responsibilities as reasonably required by business needs. "Hörmətli" Unibank və Unibank Careers paylaşılan bir vakansiya hekayəsi "SQL Developer axtarılır" – oxuyursan, amma sonda elə bil Iron Man axtarırlar.Vakansiyada ən az 6 şəxsin işi birləşdirilib:- Tətbiqi sistemlərin quraşdırılması (DevOps işi)- Problemlərin izlənməsi və həlli (Support və ya QA işi)- Proyektlərin hazırlanması (Developer işi)- APEX tətbiqlərinin təkmilləşdirilməsi (Frontend işi)- Testləşdirmə (Tester işi)- Kredit məhsulları sahəsində bilik (Business Analyst işi?) Təsəvvür et:– Oracle SQL bilirsən,– PL/SQL ilə sistem qurursan,– APEX ilə interfeysləri düzəldirsən,– Sistemi sazlayırsan,– Support verirsən,– Test edirsən,– Kredit məhsullarını da bilirsən…və bütün bunlar 2 il təcrübə ilə!Qardaş, bu 2 il NASA-da keçibsə, bəlkə mümkündür.Üstəlik "stressə davamlılıq" da vacibdir – çünki bu qədər işi bir adama verəndə davam gətirməsən, tətbiqi sistemlər deyil, namizəd çökür.Bəzən elə gəlir ki, vakansiya yox, Marvel üçün superqəhrəman kastinqidir.Əziz HR dostlar, biz developerik, transformer yox. 🚀 Master Your Interviews: A 10-Post Journey Post 6: “Why Do You Want to Leave Your Current Job?” — Without Sounding Bitter or FakeThis one always hits a nerve.You’re asked why you want to leave…So most people go for the usual fluff:“I’m just looking for new challenges.” Too vague. Too rehearsed. Too forgettable.Here’s a better way to handle it — with honesty, maturity, and actual signal.🎯 The 3C Rule: Clarity, Constructiveness, Confidence🔹 Clarity — Be real, not ranty. Bad reasons (even if true): ❌ “My company is toxic.” ❌ “There’s too much politics.”Better: ✅ “I’ve realized I do my best work in more collaborative cultures.” ✅ “I’m looking for a place that invests in learning and development.”🔹 Constructiveness — Focus on what you’re moving toward, not just what you’re running from.Bad: ❌ “I don’t like my team structure.” Good: ✅ “I’m looking for a setup where cross-functional teams collaborate closely. That’s where I thrive.”🔹 Confidence — Frame it like a professional making a growth decision.“Over the past year, I’ve taken on more ownership — led releases, mentored juniors, and handled customer escalations. But I’ve hit a growth ceiling. I’m now looking for a role where I can build, influence strategy, and keep leveling up.”🧠 Generic but Relatable Examples Across Roles:A marketer:“I’ve grown a lot in my current role — but I’ve been doing mostly execution. I’m now ready for a position with more strategic involvement.”A backend dev:“I’ve mastered a lot in my stack — but our product is monolithic. I’d love to work on more modern systems and distributed architecture.”🔁 Bottom Line: Don’t badmouth. Don’t oversell. Just show that you’re someone who reflects, grows, and makes intentional choices. That’s what hiring managers respect.You’re not just leaving — you’re moving forward.hashtag#InterviewTips hashtag#MasterYourInterviews hashtag#CareerGrowth hashtag#RealTalk hashtag#LinkedInAdvice hashtag#QA hashtag#QualityEngineering hashtag#Testing

🚀 Master Your Interviews: A 10-Post Journey Post 6: “Why Do You Want to Leave Your Current Job?” — Without Sounding Bitter or FakeThis one always hits a nerve.You’re asked why you want to leave…So most people go for the usual fluff:“I’m just looking for new challenges.” Too vague. Too rehearsed. Too forgettable.Here’s a better way to handle it — with honesty, maturity, and actual signal.🎯 The 3C Rule: Clarity, Constructiveness, Confidence🔹 Clarity — Be real, not ranty. Bad reasons (even if true): ❌ “My company is toxic.” ❌ “There’s too much politics.”Better: ✅ “I’ve realized I do my best work in more collaborative cultures.” ✅ “I’m looking for a place that invests in learning and development.”🔹 Constructiveness — Focus on what you’re moving toward, not just what you’re running from.Bad: ❌ “I don’t like my team structure.” Good: ✅ “I’m looking for a setup where cross-functional teams collaborate closely. That’s where I thrive.”🔹 Confidence — Frame it like a professional making a growth decision.“Over the past year, I’ve taken on more ownership — led releases, mentored juniors, and handled customer escalations. But I’ve hit a growth ceiling. I’m now looking for a role where I can build, influence strategy, and keep leveling up.”🧠 Generic but Relatable Examples Across Roles:A marketer:“I’ve grown a lot in my current role — but I’ve been doing mostly execution. I’m now ready for a position with more strategic involvement.”A backend dev:“I’ve mastered a lot in my stack — but our product is monolithic. I’d love to work on more modern systems and distributed architecture.”🔁 Bottom Line: Don’t badmouth. Don’t oversell. Just show that you’re someone who reflects, grows, and makes intentional choices. That’s what hiring managers respect.You’re not just leaving — you’re moving forward.hashtag#InterviewTips hashtag#MasterYourInterviews hashtag#CareerGrowth hashtag#RealTalk hashtag#LinkedInAdvice hashtag#QA hashtag#QualityEngineering hashtag#Testing

🚀 Master Your Interviews: A 10-Post Journey Post 6: “Why Do You Want to Leave Your Current Job?” — Without Sounding Bitter or FakeThis one always hits a nerve.You’re asked why you want to leave…So most people go for the usual fluff:“I’m just looking for new challenges.” Too vague. Too rehearsed. Too forgettable.Here’s a better way to handle it — with honesty, maturity, and actual signal.🎯 The 3C Rule: Clarity, Constructiveness, Confidence🔹 Clarity — Be real, not ranty. Bad reasons (even if true): ❌ “My company is toxic.” ❌ “There’s too much politics.”Better: ✅ “I’ve realized I do my best work in more collaborative cultures.” ✅ “I’m looking for a place that invests in learning and development.”🔹 Constructiveness — Focus on what you’re moving toward, not just what you’re running from.Bad: ❌ “I don’t like my team structure.” Good: ✅ “I’m looking for a setup where cross-functional teams collaborate closely. That’s where I thrive.”🔹 Confidence — Frame it like a professional making a growth decision.“Over the past year, I’ve taken on more ownership — led releases, mentored juniors, and handled customer escalations. But I’ve hit a growth ceiling. I’m now looking for a role where I can build, influence strategy, and keep leveling up.”🧠 Generic but Relatable Examples Across Roles:A marketer:“I’ve grown a lot in my current role — but I’ve been doing mostly execution. I’m now ready for a position with more strategic involvement.”A backend dev:“I’ve mastered a lot in my stack — but our product is monolithic. I’d love to work on more modern systems and distributed architecture.”🔁 Bottom Line: Don’t badmouth. Don’t oversell. Just show that you’re someone who reflects, grows, and makes intentional choices. That’s what hiring managers respect.You’re not just leaving — you’re moving forward.hashtag#InterviewTips hashtag#MasterYourInterviews hashtag#CareerGrowth hashtag#RealTalk hashtag#LinkedInAdvice hashtag#QA hashtag#QualityEngineering hashtag#Testing

🚀 Master Your Interviews: A 10-Post Journey Post 6: “Why Do You Want to Leave Your Current Job?” — Without Sounding Bitter or FakeThis one always hits a nerve.You’re asked why you want to leave…So most people go for the usual fluff:“I’m just looking for new challenges.” Too vague. Too rehearsed. Too forgettable.Here’s a better way to handle it — with honesty, maturity, and actual signal.🎯 The 3C Rule: Clarity, Constructiveness, Confidence🔹 Clarity — Be real, not ranty. Bad reasons (even if true): ❌ “My company is toxic.” ❌ “There’s too much politics.”Better: ✅ “I’ve realized I do my best work in more collaborative cultures.” ✅ “I’m looking for a place that invests in learning and development.”🔹 Constructiveness — Focus on what you’re moving toward, not just what you’re running from.Bad: ❌ “I don’t like my team structure.” Good: ✅ “I’m looking for a setup where cross-functional teams collaborate closely. That’s where I thrive.”🔹 Confidence — Frame it like a professional making a growth decision.“Over the past year, I’ve taken on more ownership — led releases, mentored juniors, and handled customer escalations. But I’ve hit a growth ceiling. I’m now looking for a role where I can build, influence strategy, and keep leveling up.”🧠 Generic but Relatable Examples Across Roles:A marketer:“I’ve grown a lot in my current role — but I’ve been doing mostly execution. I’m now ready for a position with more strategic involvement.”A backend dev:“I’ve mastered a lot in my stack — but our product is monolithic. I’d love to work on more modern systems and distributed architecture.”🔁 Bottom Line: Don’t badmouth. Don’t oversell. Just show that you’re someone who reflects, grows, and makes intentional choices. That’s what hiring managers respect.You’re not just leaving — you’re moving forward.hashtag#InterviewTips hashtag#MasterYourInterviews hashtag#CareerGrowth hashtag#RealTalk hashtag#LinkedInAdvice hashtag#QA hashtag#QualityEngineering hashtag#Testing

from the owning company/developer, understanding their needs and ensuring project design deliverables meet their expectations.· Liaise with the client representatives, contractor, site engineers, project engineers and subcontractors on all matters related to Architectural and Interior Architectural work.Design Management/Co-ordination: · Oversee and manage all Architectural/interior Design activities at renovation/new build projects. · Demonstrate a deep understanding of furniture, fixtures, and equipment to curate stylish and comfortable interiors.· Co-ordinate with the consultants and get all design & FF&E documentation prepared which is required for Tender and further to issue for site execution.Technical/Design Review: · Work closely with the Design Consultants and obtain the required design deliverables.· Review design packages/drawings & other submittals issued by the consultants to ensure its completeness, accuracy and quality before submission to owner/client for approval.· Prepare full FF&E presentation and finishes for owner/client reviewSupervision: · Support the Project Management team in resolving design-related challenges during fitout and execution.· Perform quality control checks on the executed Architectural works and prepare snagging list on FF&E and Interior works.Supplier/Vendor Management: · Carry out Inspection for the pre-qualification and approval of manufacturers and suppliers for various items such as furniture, lights and other finishing items.Quality Control: · Conduct design and constructability assessments, technical reviews, and QA/QC evaluations on the design package.· Review performance of consultants & contractors based on the KPI and prepare a list of best performers to be utilised in upcoming projectsData Bank / Library: · Maintain and update a comprehensive database of finish materials, mood boards, and matrix tables for quick reference and approval.Qualifications:· Diploma/Bachelor’s degree in Architecture or Interior Designing.· Proven minimum 5 years’ experience in Architectural Coordination and managing High End Villa projects.· Strong knowledge of construction and Architectural materials and FF&E.· Experience as Site architect.Skills:· Strong understanding of design principles, construction methodologies, and relevant industry standards and proficiency in 🚀 Master Your Interviews: A 10-Post Journey Post 6: “Why Do You Want to Leave Your Current Job?” — Without Sounding Bitter or FakeThis one always hits a nerve.You’re asked why you want to leave…So most people go for the usual fluff:“I’m just looking for new challenges.” Too vague. Too rehearsed. Too forgettable.Here’s a better way to handle it — with honesty, maturity, and actual signal.🎯 The 3C Rule: Clarity, Constructiveness, Confidence🔹 Clarity — Be real, not ranty. Bad reasons (even if true): ❌ “My company is toxic.” ❌ “There’s too much politics.”Better: ✅ “I’ve realized I do my best work in more collaborative cultures.” ✅ “I’m looking for a place that invests in learning and development.”🔹 Constructiveness — Focus on what you’re moving toward, not just what you’re running from.Bad: ❌ “I don’t like my team structure.” Good: ✅ “I’m looking for a setup where cross-functional teams collaborate closely. That’s where I thrive.”🔹 Confidence — Frame it like a professional making a growth decision.“Over the past year, I’ve taken on more ownership — led releases, mentored juniors, and handled customer escalations. But I’ve hit a growth ceiling. I’m now looking for a role where I can build, influence strategy, and keep leveling up.”🧠 Generic but Relatable Examples Across Roles:A marketer:“I’ve grown a lot in my current role — but I’ve been doing mostly execution. I’m now ready for a position with more strategic involvement.”A backend dev:“I’ve mastered a lot in my stack — but our product is monolithic. I’d love to work on more modern systems and distributed architecture.”🔁 Bottom Line: Don’t badmouth. Don’t oversell. Just show that you’re someone who reflects, grows, and makes intentional choices. That’s what hiring managers respect.You’re not just leaving — you’re moving forward.hashtag#InterviewTips hashtag#MasterYourInterviews hashtag#CareerGrowth hashtag#RealTalk hashtag#LinkedInAdvice hashtag#QA hashtag#QualityEngineering hashtag#Testing

🚀 Master Your Interviews: A 10-Post Journey Post 6: “Why Do You Want to Leave Your Current Job?” — Without Sounding Bitter or FakeThis one always hits a nerve.You’re asked why you want to leave…So most people go for the usual fluff:“I’m just looking for new challenges.” Too vague. Too rehearsed. Too forgettable.Here’s a better way to handle it — with honesty, maturity, and actual signal.🎯 The 3C Rule: Clarity, Constructiveness, Confidence🔹 Clarity — Be real, not ranty. Bad reasons (even if true): ❌ “My company is toxic.” ❌ “There’s too much politics.”Better: ✅ “I’ve realized I do my best work in more collaborative cultures.” ✅ “I’m looking for a place that invests in learning and development.”🔹 Constructiveness — Focus on what you’re moving toward, not just what you’re running from.Bad: ❌ “I don’t like my team structure.” Good: ✅ “I’m looking for a setup where cross-functional teams collaborate closely. That’s where I thrive.”🔹 Confidence — Frame it like a professional making a growth decision.“Over the past year, I’ve taken on more ownership — led releases, mentored juniors, and handled customer escalations. But I’ve hit a growth ceiling. I’m now looking for a role where I can build, influence strategy, and keep leveling up.”🧠 Generic but Relatable Examples Across Roles:A marketer:“I’ve grown a lot in my current role — but I’ve been doing mostly execution. I’m now ready for a position with more strategic involvement.”A backend dev:“I’ve mastered a lot in my stack — but our product is monolithic. I’d love to work on more modern systems and distributed architecture.”🔁 Bottom Line: Don’t badmouth. Don’t oversell. Just show that you’re someone who reflects, grows, and makes intentional choices. That’s what hiring managers respect.You’re not just leaving — you’re moving forward.hashtag#InterviewTips hashtag#MasterYourInterviews hashtag#CareerGrowth hashtag#RealTalk hashtag#LinkedInAdvice hashtag#QA hashtag#QualityEngineering hashtag#Testing

🚀 Master Your Interviews: A 10-Post Journey Post 6: “Why Do You Want to Leave Your Current Job?” — Without Sounding Bitter or FakeThis one always hits a nerve.You’re asked why you want to leave…So most people go for the usual fluff:“I’m just looking for new challenges.” Too vague. Too rehearsed. Too forgettable.Here’s a better way to handle it — with honesty, maturity, and actual signal.🎯 The 3C Rule: Clarity, Constructiveness, Confidence🔹 Clarity — Be real, not ranty. Bad reasons (even if true): ❌ “My company is toxic.” ❌ “There’s too much politics.”Better: ✅ “I’ve realized I do my best work in more collaborative cultures.” ✅ “I’m looking for a place that invests in learning and development.”🔹 Constructiveness — Focus on what you’re moving toward, not just what you’re running from.Bad: ❌ “I don’t like my team structure.” Good: ✅ “I’m looking for a setup where cross-functional teams collaborate closely. That’s where I thrive.”🔹 Confidence — Frame it like a professional making a growth decision.“Over the past year, I’ve taken on more ownership — led releases, mentored juniors, and handled customer escalations. But I’ve hit a growth ceiling. I’m now looking for a role where I can build, influence strategy, and keep leveling up.”🧠 Generic but Relatable Examples Across Roles:A marketer:“I’ve grown a lot in my current role — but I’ve been doing mostly execution. I’m now ready for a position with more strategic involvement.”A backend dev:“I’ve mastered a lot in my stack — but our product is monolithic. I’d love to work on more modern systems and distributed architecture.”🔁 Bottom Line: Don’t badmouth. Don’t oversell. Just show that you’re someone who reflects, grows, and makes intentional choices. That’s what hiring managers respect.You’re not just leaving — you’re moving forward.hashtag#InterviewTips hashtag#MasterYourInterviews hashtag#CareerGrowth hashtag#RealTalk hashtag#LinkedInAdvice hashtag#QA hashtag#QualityEngineering hashtag#Testing

Dear Hiring Team, I am Oscar Martinez Robledo, a systems engineer with over 5 years of experience as a QA Engineer. I specialize in manual testing and have experience in automation. I have worked on E-Commerce and ERP projects, using tools like Java, Selenium, SQL Server, and Postman. We are hiring!!!!Title: Project Management Specialist ILocation: San Diego, CA 92121Job Duration: 12 Months + (Possibilities chance of extension) DescriptionShift timing: 8am – 5pmInterview Process: initial phone screen, then onsite panel interviewIs There a Likelihood Of An Extension Past The Initial Duration: yes Essential Duties and Responsibilities:Requirements:Must have medical device experience.Previous project analyst or project coord experience supporting program managers in the pastStrong communication, must be able to communicate with upper leadershipAble to work independentlyBackground ExperienceScientific or engineering experience would be preferredEssential Duties and ResponsibilitiesThe incumbent may be asked to perform other function-related activities and the below-mentioned responsibilities as reasonably required by business needs. Supports a more senior project manager on programs with a broad multidisciplinary and or technical scope.Assists in maintaining master schedules, resources, and project budget.Assists in tracking, managing, and facilitating the resolution of project risks and issues.Processes and maintains design control documentation and Design History Files, per procedures.Maintains design control documentation supporting design inputs, risk, and other trace matrix data.Drafts core team-specific design control documents (e.g., project plans, traces) for team review.Coordinates design reviews, deliverables, and reviews information. Ensures action items are resolved and documented.Interacts with team members, including senior-level staff, in driving the completion of deliverables.Communicates status of project deliverables to core team leader, team members, and stakeholders.Other duties as assigned.Liaison with QA Auditors for audit of DHF, as needed.QualificationsEducation:BS Degree in Science or EngineeringProject Management coursework or certification desirable (e.g., CAPM, PMP)Experience:2 - 5 years of experience in a regulated industry, ideally supporting project teamsFamiliarity with Design Controls and Regulatory Requirements.SkillsTo perform this job successfully, an individual must be able to perform each essential duty satisfactorily. The requirements listed below are representative of the basic knowledge, skills, and/or abilities required:Knowledge of some aspects of project management (timelines, budget, financials)Proficient with the use of project management tools (e.g., MS Project, Smartsheet, JIRA, Asana, Planview) to manage projectsExcellent organization skills, and attention to detailAbility to interact effectively with personnel from top to bottom of the organization with diverse cultural and educational backgrounds.Good communication and problem-solving ability.

"Hörmətli" Unibank və Unibank Careers paylaşılan bir vakansiya hekayəsi "SQL Developer axtarılır" – oxuyursan, amma sonda elə bil Iron Man axtarırlar.Vakansiyada ən az 6 şəxsin işi birləşdirilib:- Tətbiqi sistemlərin quraşdırılması (DevOps işi)- Problemlərin izlənməsi və həlli (Support və ya QA işi)- Proyektlərin hazırlanması (Developer işi)- APEX tətbiqlərinin təkmilləşdirilməsi (Frontend işi)- Testləşdirmə (Tester işi)- Kredit məhsulları sahəsində bilik (Business Analyst işi?) Təsəvvür et:– Oracle SQL bilirsən,– PL/SQL ilə sistem qurursan,– APEX ilə interfeysləri düzəldirsən,– Sistemi sazlayırsan,– Support verirsən,– Test edirsən,– Kredit məhsullarını da bilirsən…və bütün bunlar 2 il təcrübə ilə!Qardaş, bu 2 il NASA-da keçibsə, bəlkə mümkündür.Üstəlik "stressə davamlılıq" da vacibdir – çünki bu qədər işi bir adama verəndə davam gətirməsən, tətbiqi sistemlər deyil, namizəd çökür.Bəzən elə gəlir ki, vakansiya yox, Marvel üçün superqəhrəman kastinqidir.Əziz HR dostlar, biz developerik, transformer yox. 🚀 Master Your Interviews: A 10-Post Journey Post 6: “Why Do You Want to Leave Your Current Job?” — Without Sounding Bitter or FakeThis one always hits a nerve.You’re asked why you want to leave…So most people go for the usual fluff:“I’m just looking for new challenges.” Too vague. Too rehearsed. Too forgettable.Here’s a better way to handle it — with honesty, maturity, and actual signal.🎯 The 3C Rule: Clarity, Constructiveness, Confidence🔹 Clarity — Be real, not ranty. Bad reasons (even if true): ❌ “My company is toxic.” ❌ “There’s too much politics.”Better: ✅ “I’ve realized I do my best work in more collaborative cultures.” ✅ “I’m looking for a place that invests in learning and development.”🔹 Constructiveness — Focus on what you’re moving toward, not just what you’re running from.Bad: ❌ “I don’t like my team structure.” Good: ✅ “I’m looking for a setup where cross-functional teams collaborate closely. That’s where I thrive.”🔹 Confidence — Frame it like a professional making a growth decision.“Over the past year, I’ve taken on more ownership — led releases, mentored juniors, and handled customer escalations. But I’ve hit a growth ceiling. I’m now looking for a role where I can build, influence strategy, and keep leveling up.”🧠 Generic but Relatable Examples Across Roles:A marketer:“I’ve grown a lot in my current role — but I’ve been doing mostly execution. I’m now ready for a position with more strategic involvement.”A backend dev:“I’ve mastered a lot in my stack — but our product is monolithic. I’d love to work on more modern systems and distributed architecture.”🔁 Bottom Line: Don’t badmouth. Don’t oversell. Just show that you’re someone who reflects, grows, and makes intentional choices. That’s what hiring managers respect.You’re not just leaving — you’re moving forward.hashtag#InterviewTips hashtag#MasterYourInterviews hashtag#CareerGrowth hashtag#RealTalk hashtag#LinkedInAdvice hashtag#QA hashtag#QualityEngineering hashtag#Testing

We are hiring!!!!Title: Project Management Specialist ILocation: San Diego, CA 92121Job Duration: 12 Months + (Possibilities chance of extension) DescriptionShift timing: 8am – 5pmInterview Process: initial phone screen, then onsite panel interviewIs There a Likelihood Of An Extension Past The Initial Duration: yes Essential Duties and Responsibilities:Requirements:Must have medical device experience.Previous project analyst or project coord experience supporting program managers in the pastStrong communication, must be able to communicate with upper leadershipAble to work independentlyBackground ExperienceScientific or engineering experience would be preferredEssential Duties and ResponsibilitiesThe incumbent may be asked to perform other function-related activities and the below-mentioned responsibilities as reasonably required by business needs. The requirements listed below are representative of the basic knowledge, skills, and/or abilities required:Knowledge of some aspects of project management (timelines, budget, financials)Proficient with the use of project management tools (e.g., MS Project, Smartsheet, JIRA, Asana, Planview) to manage projectsExcellent organization skills, and attention to detailAbility to interact effectively with personnel from top to bottom of the organization with diverse cultural and educational backgrounds.Good communication and problem-solving ability.

🚀 Master Your Interviews: A 10-Post Journey Post 6: “Why Do You Want to Leave Your Current Job?” — Without Sounding Bitter or FakeThis one always hits a nerve.You’re asked why you want to leave…So most people go for the usual fluff:“I’m just looking for new challenges.” Too vague. Too rehearsed. Too forgettable.Here’s a better way to handle it — with honesty, maturity, and actual signal.🎯 The 3C Rule: Clarity, Constructiveness, Confidence🔹 Clarity — Be real, not ranty. Bad reasons (even if true): ❌ “My company is toxic.” ❌ “There’s too much politics.”Better: ✅ “I’ve realized I do my best work in more collaborative cultures.” ✅ “I’m looking for a place that invests in learning and development.”🔹 Constructiveness — Focus on what you’re moving toward, not just what you’re running from.Bad: ❌ “I don’t like my team structure.” Good: ✅ “I’m looking for a setup where cross-functional teams collaborate closely. That’s where I thrive.”🔹 Confidence — Frame it like a professional making a growth decision.“Over the past year, I’ve taken on more ownership — led releases, mentored juniors, and handled customer escalations. But I’ve hit a growth ceiling. I’m now looking for a role where I can build, influence strategy, and keep leveling up.”🧠 Generic but Relatable Examples Across Roles:A marketer:“I’ve grown a lot in my current role — but I’ve been doing mostly execution. I’m now ready for a position with more strategic involvement.”A backend dev:“I’ve mastered a lot in my stack — but our product is monolithic. I’d love to work on more modern systems and distributed architecture.”🔁 Bottom Line: Don’t badmouth. Don’t oversell. Just show that you’re someone who reflects, grows, and makes intentional choices. That’s what hiring managers respect.You’re not just leaving — you’re moving forward.hashtag#InterviewTips hashtag#MasterYourInterviews hashtag#CareerGrowth hashtag#RealTalk hashtag#LinkedInAdvice hashtag#QA hashtag#QualityEngineering hashtag#Testing

🚀 Master Your Interviews: A 10-Post Journey Post 6: “Why Do You Want to Leave Your Current Job?” — Without Sounding Bitter or FakeThis one always hits a nerve.You’re asked why you want to leave…So most people go for the usual fluff:“I’m just looking for new challenges.” Too vague. Too rehearsed. Too forgettable.Here’s a better way to handle it — with honesty, maturity, and actual signal.🎯 The 3C Rule: Clarity, Constructiveness, Confidence🔹 Clarity — Be real, not ranty. Bad reasons (even if true): ❌ “My company is toxic.” ❌ “There’s too much politics.”Better: ✅ “I’ve realized I do my best work in more collaborative cultures.” ✅ “I’m looking for a place that invests in learning and development.”🔹 Constructiveness — Focus on what you’re moving toward, not just what you’re running from.Bad: ❌ “I don’t like my team structure.” Good: ✅ “I’m looking for a setup where cross-functional teams collaborate closely. That’s where I thrive.”🔹 Confidence — Frame it like a professional making a growth decision.“Over the past year, I’ve taken on more ownership — led releases, mentored juniors, and handled customer escalations. But I’ve hit a growth ceiling. I’m now looking for a role where I can build, influence strategy, and keep leveling up.”🧠 Generic but Relatable Examples Across Roles:A marketer:“I’ve grown a lot in my current role — but I’ve been doing mostly execution. I’m now ready for a position with more strategic involvement.”A backend dev:“I’ve mastered a lot in my stack — but our product is monolithic. I’d love to work on more modern systems and distributed architecture.”🔁 Bottom Line: Don’t badmouth. Don’t oversell. Just show that you’re someone who reflects, grows, and makes intentional choices. That’s what hiring managers respect.You’re not just leaving — you’re moving forward.hashtag#InterviewTips hashtag#MasterYourInterviews hashtag#CareerGrowth hashtag#RealTalk hashtag#LinkedInAdvice hashtag#QA hashtag#QualityEngineering hashtag#Testing

🚀 Master Your Interviews: A 10-Post Journey Post 6: “Why Do You Want to Leave Your Current Job?” — Without Sounding Bitter or FakeThis one always hits a nerve.You’re asked why you want to leave…So most people go for the usual fluff:“I’m just looking for new challenges.” Too vague. Too rehearsed. Too forgettable.Here’s a better way to handle it — with honesty, maturity, and actual signal.🎯 The 3C Rule: Clarity, Constructiveness, Confidence🔹 Clarity — Be real, not ranty. Bad reasons (even if true): ❌ “My company is toxic.” ❌ “There’s too much politics.”Better: ✅ “I’ve realized I do my best work in more collaborative cultures.” ✅ “I’m looking for a place that invests in learning and development.”🔹 Constructiveness — Focus on what you’re moving toward, not just what you’re running from.Bad: ❌ “I don’t like my team structure.” Good: ✅ “I’m looking for a setup where cross-functional teams collaborate closely. That’s where I thrive.”🔹 Confidence — Frame it like a professional making a growth decision.“Over the past year, I’ve taken on more ownership — led releases, mentored juniors, and handled customer escalations. But I’ve hit a growth ceiling. I’m now looking for a role where I can build, influence strategy, and keep leveling up.”🧠 Generic but Relatable Examples Across Roles:A marketer:“I’ve grown a lot in my current role — but I’ve been doing mostly execution. I’m now ready for a position with more strategic involvement.”A backend dev:“I’ve mastered a lot in my stack — but our product is monolithic. I’d love to work on more modern systems and distributed architecture.”🔁 Bottom Line: Don’t badmouth. Don’t oversell. Just show that you’re someone who reflects, grows, and makes intentional choices. That’s what hiring managers respect.You’re not just leaving — you’re moving forward.hashtag#InterviewTips hashtag#MasterYourInterviews hashtag#CareerGrowth hashtag#RealTalk hashtag#LinkedInAdvice hashtag#QA hashtag#QualityEngineering hashtag#Testing

This role is placed within Oil & Gas, Construction, Nuclear or highly regulated industry. RoleAs an EC&I - Electrical Controls and Instrumentation Quality Engineer your role will be 80% Quality assurance (LTQR compilation and review) and 20% project facing (inspection, walk rounds, tool box talks).  Main ResponsibilitiesAs a EC&I Quality Engineer you will be responsible to perform a wide range of QA Engineering tasks, Prepare and review Inspection and Test Plans and supporting Quality documentation. Provide Quality related technical support for projects. You will review vendor/supplier Inspection and Test Plans and liaise with E&I Completions and Commissioning Engineers, Project Engineers and Construction Operatives in relation to compilation of LTQR (Life Time Quality Records). You will liaise with 3rd party E&I inspectors and co-ordinate the Inspection function, raise Continuous Improvement Forms (CIFs) and ensure all quality documentation/records are maintained within the Company's Business Management System. Quality Auditing - Internal & External with supplier auditing experience desirable  Qualifications EC&I Quality Engineer should have demonstrable and current experience in ITP and LTQR production, compilation and review (essential) in E&I disciplineGood Engineering and QA/QC background and Knowledge and experience in Quality Management SystemsEC&I Quality Engineer should be able to read and understand and electrical schematics and Understanding of and familiarity with standards and specifications+3 Years' experience working in a highly regulated industry (Nuclear/Oil & Gas Construction)Member of Professional Engineering Institute (Desirable)/ Member of Chartered Quality Institute (Desirable)Current CSCS card (Essential) and Obtain security clearance SC A relevant testing and inspection qualification i.e. C&G 2391 Testing & Inspection that will support Inspection Test Plans (ITP) and Lifetime Quality Records (LTQR) production, compilation and review.   If you feel you have the experience and qualifications to succeed in this role, then please apply using the link.  This vacancy is being advertised by Belcan

🚀 Master Your Interviews: A 10-Post Journey Post 6: “Why Do You Want to Leave Your Current Job?” — Without Sounding Bitter or FakeThis one always hits a nerve.You’re asked why you want to leave…So most people go for the usual fluff:“I’m just looking for new challenges.” Too vague. Too rehearsed. Too forgettable.Here’s a better way to handle it — with honesty, maturity, and actual signal.🎯 The 3C Rule: Clarity, Constructiveness, Confidence🔹 Clarity — Be real, not ranty. Bad reasons (even if true): ❌ “My company is toxic.” ❌ “There’s too much politics.”Better: ✅ “I’ve realized I do my best work in more collaborative cultures.” ✅ “I’m looking for a place that invests in learning and development.”🔹 Constructiveness — Focus on what you’re moving toward, not just what you’re running from.Bad: ❌ “I don’t like my team structure.” Good: ✅ “I’m looking for a setup where cross-functional teams collaborate closely. That’s where I thrive.”🔹 Confidence — Frame it like a professional making a growth decision.“Over the past year, I’ve taken on more ownership — led releases, mentored juniors, and handled customer escalations. But I’ve hit a growth ceiling. I’m now looking for a role where I can build, influence strategy, and keep leveling up.”🧠 Generic but Relatable Examples Across Roles:A marketer:“I’ve grown a lot in my current role — but I’ve been doing mostly execution. I’m now ready for a position with more strategic involvement.”A backend dev:“I’ve mastered a lot in my stack — but our product is monolithic. I’d love to work on more modern systems and distributed architecture.”🔁 Bottom Line: Don’t badmouth. Don’t oversell. Just show that you’re someone who reflects, grows, and makes intentional choices. That’s what hiring managers respect.You’re not just leaving — you’re moving forward.hashtag#InterviewTips hashtag#MasterYourInterviews hashtag#CareerGrowth hashtag#RealTalk hashtag#LinkedInAdvice hashtag#QA hashtag#QualityEngineering hashtag#Testing

hashtag#hiring *EC&I Quality Engineer*, Reading, *United Kingdom*, contract hashtag#opentowork hashtag#Readingjobs hashtag#Berkshirejobs hashtag#Engineering hashtag#outsideir35 hashtag#ir35 *To Apply -->*: https://lnkd.in/g4ne_hpu Job title: Quality Engineer EC&ILocation: ReadingJob type: Contract (Outside IR35) Our Client an Engineering company are seeking an Electrical Controls and Instrumentation Quality Engineer for a 6-month contract position in Reading location. This role is placed within Oil & Gas, Construction, Nuclear or highly regulated industry. RoleAs an EC&I - Electrical Controls and Instrumentation Quality Engineer your role will be 80% Quality assurance (LTQR compilation and review) and 20% project facing (inspection, walk rounds, tool box talks).  Main ResponsibilitiesAs a EC&I Quality Engineer you will be responsible to perform a wide range of QA Engineering tasks, Prepare and review Inspection and Test Plans and supporting Quality documentation. Provide Quality related technical support for projects. You will review vendor/supplier Inspection and Test Plans and liaise with E&I Completions and Commissioning Engineers, Project Engineers and Construction Operatives in relation to compilation of LTQR (Life Time Quality Records). You will liaise with 3rd party E&I inspectors and co-ordinate the Inspection function, raise Continuous Improvement Forms (CIFs) and ensure all quality documentation/records are maintained within the Company's Business Management System. Quality Auditing - Internal & External with supplier auditing experience desirable  Qualifications EC&I Quality Engineer should have demonstrable and current experience in ITP and LTQR production, compilation and review (essential) in E&I disciplineGood Engineering and QA/QC background and Knowledge and experience in Quality Management SystemsEC&I Quality Engineer should be able to read and understand and electrical schematics and Understanding of and familiarity with standards and specifications+3 Years' experience working in a highly regulated industry (Nuclear/Oil & Gas Construction)Member of Professional Engineering Institute (Desirable)/ Member of Chartered Quality Institute (Desirable)Current CSCS card (Essential) and Obtain security clearance SC A relevant testing and inspection qualification i.e. C&G 2391 Testing & Inspection that will support Inspection Test Plans (ITP) and Lifetime Quality Records (LTQR) production, compilation and review.   If you feel you have the experience and qualifications to succeed in this role, then please apply using the link.  This vacancy is being advertised by Belcan

🚀 Master Your Interviews: A 10-Post Journey Post 6: “Why Do You Want to Leave Your Current Job?” — Without Sounding Bitter or FakeThis one always hits a nerve.You’re asked why you want to leave…So most people go for the usual fluff:“I’m just looking for new challenges.” Too vague. Too rehearsed. Too forgettable.Here’s a better way to handle it — with honesty, maturity, and actual signal.🎯 The 3C Rule: Clarity, Constructiveness, Confidence🔹 Clarity — Be real, not ranty. Bad reasons (even if true): ❌ “My company is toxic.” ❌ “There’s too much politics.”Better: ✅ “I’ve realized I do my best work in more collaborative cultures.” ✅ “I’m looking for a place that invests in learning and development.”🔹 Constructiveness — Focus on what you’re moving toward, not just what you’re running from.Bad: ❌ “I don’t like my team structure.” Good: ✅ “I’m looking for a setup where cross-functional teams collaborate closely. That’s where I thrive.”🔹 Confidence — Frame it like a professional making a growth decision.“Over the past year, I’ve taken on more ownership — led releases, mentored juniors, and handled customer escalations. But I’ve hit a growth ceiling. I’m now looking for a role where I can build, influence strategy, and keep leveling up.”🧠 Generic but Relatable Examples Across Roles:A marketer:“I’ve grown a lot in my current role — but I’ve been doing mostly execution. I’m now ready for a position with more strategic involvement.”A backend dev:“I’ve mastered a lot in my stack — but our product is monolithic. I’d love to work on more modern systems and distributed architecture.”🔁 Bottom Line: Don’t badmouth. Don’t oversell. Just show that you’re someone who reflects, grows, and makes intentional choices. That’s what hiring managers respect.You’re not just leaving — you’re moving forward.hashtag#InterviewTips hashtag#MasterYourInterviews hashtag#CareerGrowth hashtag#RealTalk hashtag#LinkedInAdvice hashtag#QA hashtag#QualityEngineering hashtag#Testing

🎯 WE'RE HIRING: Quality Inspector 📍 South Africa | Energy Sector 💼 Posted by: GIEC PlacementsAre you the kind of professional who spots what others miss? If standards, safety, and accuracy are your second language, we want to hear from you.Our client, a major player in power generation, petrochemical, and mining, is seeking a meticulous Quality Inspector to uphold quality on high-profile industrial projects.🔍 Your Role in a Nutshell: 🛠️ Inspect materials, welds, and installations like a pro 📏 Enforce compliance with SAIW, NACE, ISO or equivalent standards 📄 Document non-conformities & drive corrective actions 🤝 Collaborate closely with engineering teams to embed quality at every stage🎓 What You Bring to the Table: ✅ National Diploma in Mechanical, Electrical, Civil, or Chemical Engineering ✅ NACE Level 2, SAIW, or similar QA certification (advantageous) ✅ 5+ years in power stations, petrochemical, or mining environments ✅ Strong grasp of QA/QC procedures, technical specs & field execution🚨 Why This Role? It’s not just a job — it’s a critical quality gatekeeper role in projects that matter. hashtag#hiring *EC&I Quality Engineer*, Reading, *United Kingdom*, contract hashtag#opentowork hashtag#Readingjobs hashtag#Berkshirejobs hashtag#Engineering hashtag#outsideir35 hashtag#ir35 *To Apply -->*: https://lnkd.in/g4ne_hpu Job title: Quality Engineer EC&ILocation: ReadingJob type: Contract (Outside IR35) Our Client an Engineering company are seeking an Electrical Controls and Instrumentation Quality Engineer for a 6-month contract position in Reading location. This role is placed within Oil & Gas, Construction, Nuclear or highly regulated industry. RoleAs an EC&I - Electrical Controls and Instrumentation Quality Engineer your role will be 80% Quality assurance (LTQR compilation and review) and 20% project facing (inspection, walk rounds, tool box talks).  Main ResponsibilitiesAs a EC&I Quality Engineer you will be responsible to perform a wide range of QA Engineering tasks, Prepare and review Inspection and Test Plans and supporting Quality documentation. Provide Quality related technical support for projects. You will review vendor/supplier Inspection and Test Plans and liaise with E&I Completions and Commissioning Engineers, Project Engineers and Construction Operatives in relation to compilation of LTQR (Life Time Quality Records). You will liaise with 3rd party E&I inspectors and co-ordinate the Inspection function, raise Continuous Improvement Forms (CIFs) and ensure all quality documentation/records are maintained within the Company's Business Management System. Quality Auditing - Internal & External with supplier auditing experience desirable  Qualifications EC&I Quality Engineer should have demonstrable and current experience in ITP and LTQR production, compilation and review (essential) in E&I disciplineGood Engineering and QA/QC background and Knowledge and experience in Quality Management SystemsEC&I Quality Engineer should be able to read and understand and electrical schematics and Understanding of and familiarity with standards and specifications+3 Years' experience working in a highly regulated industry (Nuclear/Oil & Gas Construction)Member of Professional Engineering Institute (Desirable)/ Member of Chartered Quality Institute (Desirable)Current CSCS card (Essential) and Obtain security clearance SC A relevant testing and inspection qualification i.e. C&G 2391 Testing & Inspection that will support Inspection Test Plans (ITP) and Lifetime Quality Records (LTQR) production, compilation and review.   If you feel you have the experience and qualifications to succeed in this role, then please apply using the link.  This vacancy is being advertised by Belcan

We are hiring!!!!Title: Project Management Specialist ILocation: San Diego, CA 92121Job Duration: 12 Months + (Possibilities chance of extension) DescriptionShift timing: 8am – 5pmInterview Process: initial phone screen, then onsite panel interviewIs There a Likelihood Of An Extension Past The Initial Duration: yes Essential Duties and Responsibilities:Requirements:Must have medical device experience.Previous project analyst or project coord experience supporting program managers in the pastStrong communication, must be able to communicate with upper leadershipAble to work independentlyBackground ExperienceScientific or engineering experience would be preferredEssential Duties and ResponsibilitiesThe incumbent may be asked to perform other function-related activities and the below-mentioned responsibilities as reasonably required by business needs. Supports a more senior project manager on programs with a broad multidisciplinary and or technical scope.Assists in maintaining master schedules, resources, and project budget.Assists in tracking, managing, and facilitating the resolution of project risks and issues.Processes and maintains design control documentation and Design History Files, per procedures.Maintains design control documentation supporting design inputs, risk, and other trace matrix data.Drafts core team-specific design control documents (e.g., project plans, traces) for team review.Coordinates design reviews, deliverables, and reviews information. Ensures action items are resolved and documented.Interacts with team members, including senior-level staff, in driving the completion of deliverables.Communicates status of project deliverables to core team leader, team members, and stakeholders.Other duties as assigned.Liaison with QA Auditors for audit of DHF, as needed.QualificationsEducation:BS Degree in Science or EngineeringProject Management coursework or certification desirable (e.g., CAPM, PMP)Experience:2 - 5 years of experience in a regulated industry, ideally supporting project teamsFamiliarity with Design Controls and Regulatory Requirements.SkillsTo perform this job successfully, an individual must be able to perform each essential duty satisfactorily. The requirements listed below are representative of the basic knowledge, skills, and/or abilities required:Knowledge of some aspects of project management (timelines, budget, financials)Proficient with the use of project management tools (e.g., MS Project, Smartsheet, JIRA, Asana, Planview) to manage projectsExcellent organization skills, and attention to detailAbility to interact effectively with personnel from top to bottom of the organization with diverse cultural and educational backgrounds.Good communication and problem-solving ability.

"Hörmətli" Unibank və Unibank Careers paylaşılan bir vakansiya hekayəsi "SQL Developer axtarılır" – oxuyursan, amma sonda elə bil Iron Man axtarırlar.Vakansiyada ən az 6 şəxsin işi birləşdirilib:- Tətbiqi sistemlərin quraşdırılması (DevOps işi)- Problemlərin izlənməsi və həlli (Support və ya QA işi)- Proyektlərin hazırlanması (Developer işi)- APEX tətbiqlərinin təkmilləşdirilməsi (Frontend işi)- Testləşdirmə (Tester işi)- Kredit məhsulları sahəsində bilik (Business Analyst işi?) Təsəvvür et:– Oracle SQL bilirsən,– PL/SQL ilə sistem qurursan,– APEX ilə interfeysləri düzəldirsən,– Sistemi sazlayırsan,– Support verirsən,– Test edirsən,– Kredit məhsullarını da bilirsən…və bütün bunlar 2 il təcrübə ilə!Qardaş, bu 2 il NASA-da keçibsə, bəlkə mümkündür.Üstəlik "stressə davamlılıq" da vacibdir – çünki bu qədər işi bir adama verəndə davam gətirməsən, tətbiqi sistemlər deyil, namizəd çökür.Bəzən elə gəlir ki, vakansiya yox, Marvel üçün superqəhrəman kastinqidir.Əziz HR dostlar, biz developerik, transformer yox. 🚀 Master Your Interviews: A 10-Post Journey Post 6: “Why Do You Want to Leave Your Current Job?” — Without Sounding Bitter or FakeThis one always hits a nerve.You’re asked why you want to leave…So most people go for the usual fluff:“I’m just looking for new challenges.” Too vague. Too rehearsed. Too forgettable.Here’s a better way to handle it — with honesty, maturity, and actual signal.🎯 The 3C Rule: Clarity, Constructiveness, Confidence🔹 Clarity — Be real, not ranty. Bad reasons (even if true): ❌ “My company is toxic.” ❌ “There’s too much politics.”Better: ✅ “I’ve realized I do my best work in more collaborative cultures.” ✅ “I’m looking for a place that invests in learning and development.”🔹 Constructiveness — Focus on what you’re moving toward, not just what you’re running from.Bad: ❌ “I don’t like my team structure.” Good: ✅ “I’m looking for a setup where cross-functional teams collaborate closely. That’s where I thrive.”🔹 Confidence — Frame it like a professional making a growth decision.“Over the past year, I’ve taken on more ownership — led releases, mentored juniors, and handled customer escalations. But I’ve hit a growth ceiling. I’m now looking for a role where I can build, influence strategy, and keep leveling up.”🧠 Generic but Relatable Examples Across Roles:A marketer:“I’ve grown a lot in my current role — but I’ve been doing mostly execution. I’m now ready for a position with more strategic involvement.”A backend dev:“I’ve mastered a lot in my stack — but our product is monolithic. I’d love to work on more modern systems and distributed architecture.”🔁 Bottom Line: Don’t badmouth. Don’t oversell. Just show that you’re someone who reflects, grows, and makes intentional choices. That’s what hiring managers respect.You’re not just leaving — you’re moving forward.hashtag#InterviewTips hashtag#MasterYourInterviews hashtag#CareerGrowth hashtag#RealTalk hashtag#LinkedInAdvice hashtag#QA hashtag#QualityEngineering hashtag#Testing

This role is placed within Oil & Gas, Construction, Nuclear or highly regulated industry. RoleAs an EC&I - Electrical Controls and Instrumentation Quality Engineer your role will be 80% Quality assurance (LTQR compilation and review) and 20% project facing (inspection, walk rounds, tool box talks).  Main ResponsibilitiesAs a EC&I Quality Engineer you will be responsible to perform a wide range of QA Engineering tasks, Prepare and review Inspection and Test Plans and supporting Quality documentation. Provide Quality related technical support for projects. You will review vendor/supplier Inspection and Test Plans and liaise with E&I Completions and Commissioning Engineers, Project Engineers and Construction Operatives in relation to compilation of LTQR (Life Time Quality Records). You will liaise with 3rd party E&I inspectors and co-ordinate the Inspection function, raise Continuous Improvement Forms (CIFs) and ensure all quality documentation/records are maintained within the Company's Business Management System. Quality Auditing - Internal & External with supplier auditing experience desirable  Qualifications EC&I Quality Engineer should have demonstrable and current experience in ITP and LTQR production, compilation and review (essential) in E&I disciplineGood Engineering and QA/QC background and Knowledge and experience in Quality Management SystemsEC&I Quality Engineer should be able to read and understand and electrical schematics and Understanding of and familiarity with standards and specifications+3 Years' experience working in a highly regulated industry (Nuclear/Oil & Gas Construction)Member of Professional Engineering Institute (Desirable)/ Member of Chartered Quality Institute (Desirable)Current CSCS card (Essential) and Obtain security clearance SC A relevant testing and inspection qualification i.e. C&G 2391 Testing & Inspection that will support Inspection Test Plans (ITP) and Lifetime Quality Records (LTQR) production, compilation and review. 🚀 Master Your Interviews: A 10-Post Journey Post 6: “Why Do You Want to Leave Your Current Job?” — Without Sounding Bitter or FakeThis one always hits a nerve.You’re asked why you want to leave…So most people go for the usual fluff:“I’m just looking for new challenges.” Too vague. Too rehearsed. Too forgettable.Here’s a better way to handle it — with honesty, maturity, and actual signal.🎯 The 3C Rule: Clarity, Constructiveness, Confidence🔹 Clarity — Be real, not ranty. Bad reasons (even if true): ❌ “My company is toxic.” ❌ “There’s too much politics.”Better: ✅ “I’ve realized I do my best work in more collaborative cultures.” ✅ “I’m looking for a place that invests in learning and development.”🔹 Constructiveness — Focus on what you’re moving toward, not just what you’re running from.Bad: ❌ “I don’t like my team structure.” Good: ✅ “I’m looking for a setup where cross-functional teams collaborate closely. That’s where I thrive.”🔹 Confidence — Frame it like a professional making a growth decision.“Over the past year, I’ve taken on more ownership — led releases, mentored juniors, and handled customer escalations. But I’ve hit a growth ceiling. I’m now looking for a role where I can build, influence strategy, and keep leveling up.”🧠 Generic but Relatable Examples Across Roles:A marketer:“I’ve grown a lot in my current role — but I’ve been doing mostly execution. I’m now ready for a position with more strategic involvement.”A backend dev:“I’ve mastered a lot in my stack — but our product is monolithic. I’d love to work on more modern systems and distributed architecture.”🔁 Bottom Line: Don’t badmouth. Don’t oversell. Just show that you’re someone who reflects, grows, and makes intentional choices. That’s what hiring managers respect.You’re not just leaving — you’re moving forward.hashtag#InterviewTips hashtag#MasterYourInterviews hashtag#CareerGrowth hashtag#RealTalk hashtag#LinkedInAdvice hashtag#QA hashtag#QualityEngineering hashtag#Testing

hashtag#hiring *EC&I Quality Engineer*, Reading, *United Kingdom*, contract hashtag#opentowork hashtag#Readingjobs hashtag#Berkshirejobs hashtag#Engineering hashtag#outsideir35 hashtag#ir35 *To Apply -->*: https://lnkd.in/g4ne_hpu Job title: Quality Engineer EC&ILocation: ReadingJob type: Contract (Outside IR35) Our Client an Engineering company are seeking an Electrical Controls and Instrumentation Quality Engineer for a 6-month contract position in Reading location. This role is placed within Oil & Gas, Construction, Nuclear or highly regulated industry. RoleAs an EC&I - Electrical Controls and Instrumentation Quality Engineer your role will be 80% Quality assurance (LTQR compilation and review) and 20% project facing (inspection, walk rounds, tool box talks).  Main ResponsibilitiesAs a EC&I Quality Engineer you will be responsible to perform a wide range of QA Engineering tasks, Prepare and review Inspection and Test Plans and supporting Quality documentation. Provide Quality related technical support for projects. You will review vendor/supplier Inspection and Test Plans and liaise with E&I Completions and Commissioning Engineers, Project Engineers and Construction Operatives in relation to compilation of LTQR (Life Time Quality Records). You will liaise with 3rd party E&I inspectors and co-ordinate the Inspection function, raise Continuous Improvement Forms (CIFs) and ensure all quality documentation/records are maintained within the Company's Business Management System. Quality Auditing - Internal & External with supplier auditing experience desirable  Qualifications EC&I Quality Engineer should have demonstrable and current experience in ITP and LTQR production, compilation and review (essential) in E&I disciplineGood Engineering and QA/QC background and Knowledge and experience in Quality Management SystemsEC&I Quality Engineer should be able to read and understand and electrical schematics and Understanding of and familiarity with standards and specifications+3 Years' experience working in a highly regulated industry (Nuclear/Oil & Gas Construction)Member of Professional Engineering Institute (Desirable)/ Member of Chartered Quality Institute (Desirable)Current CSCS card (Essential) and Obtain security clearance SC A relevant testing and inspection qualification i.e. C&G 2391 Testing & Inspection that will support Inspection Test Plans (ITP) and Lifetime Quality Records (LTQR) production, compilation and review.   If you feel you have the experience and qualifications to succeed in this role, then please apply using the link.  This vacancy is being advertised by Belcan
